Oh sorry, <@U91Q3595Y> one more: for things where the Jacobian is important.. Eg anything like constrained optimization, systems of equations, mpec, implicit solutions to differential equations, mcp,... The first order concern is always using the best algorithm, but after that Jacobian sparsity is probably the next most important.

For example, if the sparsity structure is tridiagonal you only need to evaluate 3 directional derivatives rather than one for each dimension. <https://github.com/JuliaDiff/SparseDiffTools.jl|https://github.com/JuliaDiff/SparseDiffTools.jl> provides tools for that.

This can work with both auto differentiation and finite differences... So if your function is a pain to use AD on, then finite differences might be just as good in speed (but not accuracy)
